bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Mabel H. Lazear, April 19, 1929

div1.p: Kean requests supplemental information on Jesse Lazear's life, as well as information on Mabel Lazear and her children.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Mabel H. Lazear, April 19, 1929
div1.opener:
THE ASSOCIATION OF MILITARY SURGEONS OF THE UNITED STATES
THE MILITARY SURGEON
PRESIDENT
SENIOR SURGEON C. H. LAVINDER
UNITED STATES PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
FIRST VICE-PRESIDENT
BRIGADIER GENERAL WM. H. WILMER
MEDICAL RESERVE CORPS, UNITED STATES ARMY
SECOND VICE-PRESIDENT
CAPT. JAMES C. PRYOR
MEDICAL CORPS. UNITED STATES NAVY
EDITOR AND SECRETARY
COL. JEFFERSON R. KEAN
UNITED STATES ARMY, RET.
ADDRESS ALL COMMUNICATIONS TO
THE MILITARY SURGEON
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM
WASHINGTON, D. C.
THIRD VICE-PRESIDENT
COL. CHARLES R. REYNOLDS
MEDICAL CORPS. UNITED STATES ARMY
FOURTH VICE-PRESIDENT
COL. CHARLES W. COMFORT, JR.
MEDICAL CORPS. CONNECTICUT NATIONAL GUARD
ASSISTANT EDITOR
MAJOR EDGAR ERSKINE HUME
MEDICAL CORPS. UNITED STATES ARMY
19 April, 1929.
Mrs. Jesse W. Lazear,
6 Oak Vale Ave.,
Berkeley, California.
My dear Mrs. Lazear:
div1.p:
The Surgeon General has had a request from Washington and
Jefferson College, Penna. (through a Congressman) for a sketch of your
distinguished husband to be used in connection with the erection of a tablet
to him at that school where it seems he received his early academic education.
Colonel Duncan, who happens to be on duty in the Library, has looked up
everything connected with Dr. Lazear which is now on file in the Library,
and finds that there is very little. No biography of him seems to have
been written. Inclosed is an abstract of everything that we could find.
If you have any manuscript or printed matter which could supplement this
sketch in any way, we would be glad to have it on file for future use.
If you wish to have the manuscript or material returned it will be done.
If you have not anything of this sort perhaps you would write out such
additions to the sketch as you can. We would be glad, also, to have
something about yourself, your maiden name and former home, the names
and ages of your children and where they now are, both for our own in-
formation and to meet future inquiries.

It was a great disappointment to me, as it was to The Surgeon
General, that in passing the recent legislation to honor and reward the
men who volunteered to be bitten by mosquitoes and experimented on in
other ways for the Reed Board, the Committee of Congress was not willing
to do what the Surgeon General recommended, namely, to increase the pensions
of the widows of the deceased members of the Board to $250.00. Apparently
the Chairman of the Pension Committee of the House was afraid of establishing
a troublesome precedent.

I hope you are getting along very well. I knew Dr. Lazear
very well during the spring and summer of 1900 when I was living at
Columbia Barracks.
div1.closer:
Yours sincerely, J. R. KEAN,
Colonel, U.S. Army, Retd.,
Editor. JRK/F
